Al-Mudhakarah fi Alqab al-Shu'ara (Memorandum on Poets' Nicknames)
text: Section: Biographies and Classes. Book: Al-Mudhakarah fi Alqab al-Shu'ara. Author: Abu al-Majd As'ad bin Ibrahim al-Shaybani al-Irbili, known as Majd al-Din al-Nashabi al-Katib (d. 657 AH). [The book is automatically numbered and does not correspond to the printed version]. Number of pages: 66. Published in Al-Shamela: 8 Dhu al-Hijjah 1431.

In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. [This work is] known as 'The Unique Pearl of the Age regarding the Virtues of the Contemporaries.' I have dedicated it to the library of the Great Master, the Scholar, the Just, the Mujahid, the Supported, the Victorious, the Triumphant, Taj al-Din, Glory of Islam, Support of the People, Sword of the State, Lion of the Nation, Helper of the Mujahideen, Conqueror of Rebels, Doing Justice to the Oppressed against the Oppressors, Pride of the Chiefs, Backer of the Public, Choice of the Honored Imamate, Groom of the Exalted Caliphate, the Noble of Iraq, of Pure Roots, Support of the Muslims, Brother of Kings and Sultans, Sword of the Commander of the Faithful, Abu al-Futuh Ali bin... and may his club flourish with praise and thanksgiving. I apologize for any oversight that occurs or breach that cannot be patched. He who requires pardon accepts purity, for no one is free from fault, nor is a pen lifted from a writer.

Abu Ubaidah said: The poets of the Jahiliyyah are three: Imru' al-Qays, Al-Nabigha, and Zuhayr. We will mention them and those after them with the utmost brevity and appropriate summarization, for a memorandum does not bear elaboration or boredom. I have mentioned only the rare and beautiful anecdotes and poets known only to a few notables. I began by mentioning the nicknamed poets, some of whom were nicknamed for a verse they said, others for a physical mark, a visible color, a famous deed, their city, or their kunya (surname).

**Poets' Nicknames**

**Chapter: Those Nicknamed for Poetry They Spoke**

Among the poets nicknamed for a verse is **Mudrij al-Rih** (The Wind-Dragger). He said:
'Did you recognize a trace of Sumayya at Al-Liwa... The wind dragged over it after you, so it became leveled.'
It is narrated that when he composed half of this verse, he got stuck and remained unable to compose the second half for a year. He had buried a cache in the very dwellings where he used to stay. He remembered it and told his servant girl to go and dig up the cache from that wilderness, giving her its signs. The girl went, but the winds had shifted over those lands and erased their traces. She returned finding nothing. He asked her about the situation, and she said: 'The wind dragged over it after you, so it became leveled.' He completed his verse with this and was named Mudrij al-Rih.

**Al-Muraqqish**: His name was Amr bin Sufyan (Al-Muraqqish the Younger). He was named Al-Muraqqish because his face was speckled. Or because he said: 'As a pen writes (raqasha) on the back of leather.'

**Al-Mumazzaq** (The Torn): For his saying:
'If I am to be eaten, then you be my eater... Otherwise, overtake me while I am not torn apart.'
It is said Uthman wrote this verse to Ali while he was besieged.

**Al-Mukhariq** (The Shredder): Attributed himself to Al-Mumazzaq, saying:
'I am the shredder of the honor of the mean, just as... Al-Mumazzaq was [shredder] of the honor of the mean, my father.'

**Al-Muthaqqib** (The Piercer): His name is A'idh bin al-Ahmar. Named for his saying:
'They showed beauties and hid others... And they pierced the face-veils for the eyes.'
Or for his saying:
'No litters—my longing is not for them—nor the piercing stars (Al-Thaqibat) of Lu'ayy bin Ghalib.'

**Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani**: His name is Ziyad bin Muawiyah. Named Al-Nabigha (The one who bursts forth) for his saying:
'And she settled among Banu Qayn bin Jasr... And affairs have burst forth (nabaghat), not from them.'
Others said: He was named Al-Nabigha because he burst forth in poetry late in life. There are four Nabighas: Of Banu Dhubyan, Banu Ja'da (Qays bin Abdullah), Banu al-Harith (Yazid bin Aban), and Banu Shayban (Abdullah bin al-Mukhariq). They were named so because they started poetry when they were old.

**Al-Khalaj**: His name is Najiya bin Malik. Named for his saying:
'As if the pulling (takhaluj) of the ropes in it... were downpours pouring with the morning clouds.'

**Shuqrah**: His name is Muawiyah bin al-Harith. Named for his saying:
'I may carry the spear with solid knots... having on it from the blood of the people something like anemones (Al-Shuqrat).'
Al-Shuqrat refers to the red anemones (Shaqa'iq). They were named so because Al-Nu'man built a sitting place called Al-Dahik and planted anemones there, so they were called Shaqa'iq al-Nu'man.

**Al-Mufaddal**: His name is Amir bin Ma'shar. Named for his saying in his poem:
'We made their women cry, and they made... women cry whose saliva does not flow easily (from grief).'

**Al-Muqrid** (The Lender/Clipper): His name is Zahdam bin Ma'd. Named for saying:
'And I am the lender against the sides... of the betrayers, for every neighbor.
The lending (clipping) of a fire-striker's flint... in all of it, fire is kindled.'

**Al-Mikwat** (The Cautery/Iron): His name is Abdullah bin Khalid. Named so for frequently mentioning cauterization in his poetry, and for his saying:
'And one like you, I have given a second drink from a cup of rage... And a proud one I have cauterized on the forehead.'

**Al-Hattat** (The Crusher): His name is Bishr bin Rudayh. Named for his saying:
'And a battlefield of heroes I witnessed, as if... I crush (ahuttu) them with the crafted Mashrafi sword.'
Al-Hatt is less than Al-Naht (carving).

**Al-Hijaff** (The Ostrich/Bulky): His name is Ka'b bin Karim. Named for his saying:
'Ibn Mu'ti hopes for her milk and attribution... A bulky ostrich (Hijaff) that shied away from the masters and went up.'
Hijaff: An aged male ostrich.

**Al-Ba'ith** (The Resurrector/Sender): His name is Khidash bin Labid. Named for his saying:
'He resurrected (taba'atha) from me what he resurrected after... my powers were twisted and my determination continued.'
Meaning: You saw my resolve. He said poetry only after becoming old.

**Dhu al-Kharq** (Owner of the Rag): His name is Ibn Shurayh. Named for his saying:
'The tied dirham does not familiarize itself with our rag... But passes over it, then departs.'

**A'mar**: His name is Munabbih. Named for his saying:
'Umayrah said: What is wrong with your head after... time has lasted; it has come with a disliked color.
O Umayrah, indeed your father's head has been whitened... by the passing of nights and the alternation of eras.'
Al-A'mar: Smoke. It is said he smoked out people in a cave, and they died.

**Qatil al-Ju'** (Killer of Hunger): His name is Imru' al-Qays bin Ka'b. Named for saying:
'I killed hunger in the winters until... I left hunger having no denier.'

**Muzarrad** (The Swallower/Strangler): His name is Yazid bin Dirar al-Kalbi. Named for saying:
'We remained turning our mother away from her ghee skin... Like people of stubbornness, all of us showing affection.
Then she brought it, yellow with lines... upon which the mistress of the butter-skin almost grieved.
So I said: Ubayd swallows (tazarrad) it, for I am... for the dregs of the clients, in the [drought] years, a swallower (Muzarrad).'

**Dhu al-Rumma** (Owner of the Old Rope): His name is Ghaylan bin Uqba. Named for saying:
'Nothing remained but traces like a stagnant... nothing but three remaining black stones.
And after a crushed neck, staked... disheveled, remaining like the old rope (rummah) of a necklace.'
Al-Rumma: The remains of a worn rope.

**Al-Qutami** (The Hawk): His name is Amr. Named for saying:
'He puts them down, side by side... As the hawk (Al-Qutami) puts down the fleeing sandgrouse.'

**Al-Hatim** (The Smasher/Crusher): His name is Nu'man bin Malik. Named for saying:
'Ask Al-Hatim today about his cloud (Gamamah)... He befriended her, and she was pleased with his friendship.'
Gamamah: A woman from Darim.

**Al-Gharib** (The Stranger): Nu'aym bin Sulaym. Named for saying:
'My name is Nu'aym, and I am the stranger... Names of a noble one; love them both.'

**A'id al-Kalb** (Visitor of the Dog): Abdullah bin Mus'ab bin Abdullah bin al-Zubayr. Named for saying:
'Why is it that I fell ill and no visitor from you visited me... Yet your dog falls ill and I visit it?'

**Al-As'ar** (The Fire-Starter): An ancient poet named Marthad bin Abi Humran. Named for saying:
'So let not my people leave me to Sa'd bin Malik... If I do not ignite (as'ar) [war] against them and pierce.'
Al-Sa'r: Kindling of fire or war. Also said to be named for the thinness of his legs.

**Al-Samit** (The Silent): Amr bin al-Ghawth. Named for saying:
'She saw me silent, having no speech... Verily, the stranger is the silent one.'

**‘Ariq** (The Gnower): Qays bin Jarwah. Named for saying:
'If we do not change some of what you have done... I will bite the bone of which I am the gnower ('ariq).'

**Al-Ajjaj** (The Clamorous): Named for saying:
'Until he cries out (ya'ujju) heavily from the clamor.'

**Al-Khatfi**: Hudhayfah bin Badr. Named for saying:
'They raise to the night when it darkens... Necks of snakes and heads trembling.
And a pace after fatigue, snatching (khaytafa).'
Khaytaf: Fast.

Among the modern poets:
**Al-Mura'ath** (The Earring Wearer): This is Bashar bin Burd. His nickname was Al-Mura'ath, a client of Uqayl, and he was blind. He was called Al-Mura'ath for saying:
'Who is for a gazelle with an earring (mura'ath)... enchanting in glance and look?
He said to me: You will not attain me... I said: Or will fate overcome?'
It is also said he was named Al-Mura'ath because he was born with a split earlobe, so they said he was born 'mura'athan', meaning he didn't need piercing.

**Shahawat** (Desires): His name was Musa. Named for saying about Yazid bin Muawiyah:
'You are not of us, and Khalid is not of us... We do not waste prayer for desires (shahawat).'

**Uwayf al-Qawafi** (Loather of Rhymes): Uwayf bin Uyayna. Named because he said:
'I shall belie him who used to claim that I... when I speak a saying, do not perfect the rhymes.'

**Al-Farrar** (The Fleer): The Prophet (PBUH) asked a prophet of Sulaym: 'To whom shall I give your banner?' They said: 'To Al-Farrar.' The Prophet disliked that. They said: 'His name is Hayyan bin al-Hakam.' He was named Al-Farrar for saying:
'And a battalion I clothed with a battalion... Until when they clashed, I shook my hand of it.
Does it benefit me that your women say... while I entrusted the rear of their remnant: Do not be far?'

**Tarafa**: His name is Amr bin al-Abd. Named Tarafa for saying:
'Do not hasten with weeping today regarding a newly acquired (mutraf) thing... Nor regarding your commander, at the abode, when they stood.'
Mutraf: Something brought from afar/strange.

**Sari' al-Ghawani** (The Victim of Beauties): Muslim bin al-Walid al-Ansari. Named so because Al-Rashid asked him to recite his poem:
'Pass the cup to me, do not drink before me.'
When he reached:
'Is life anything but to go with youth... and become a victim (sari') of the cup and wide eyes?'
Al-Rashid said: 'Name him Sari' al-Ghawani.'

**Mujtani al-Muru'ah** (The Harvester of Virtue): Abdullah bin Ahmad al-Hanafi. He was a friend of Ibn al-Muqaffa'. Named for frequently mentioning virtue (muru'ah) in his poetry, such as:
'Do not think that virtue... is food or drinking a cup,
Or in guardianship, processions... mounts, and clothing.
But it is the nobility of the branches... that thrived on the nobility of the foundation.'
And:
'Virtue is not in dirhams... Rather virtue is in noble deeds.
How many a rich man is low... and a poor man of a people possesses landmarks.'

**Chapter: Mentioning Poets Nicknamed for a Physical Mark or Color**

**Al-Akhdar** (The Green/Dark): Al-Fadl bin Abbas bin Utbah. Named Al-Akhdar because he was very dark-skinned (Adam). In Arabic, 'Al-Adam' is Green (Akhdar). They call white 'green'. Adam (peace be upon him) was named so because he was white. Al-Fadl said:
'I am the Green one, who knows me?... Green of skin from the lineage of the Arabs.'
He said: Al-Akhdar in Arabic speech also means Black. They call the night 'Akhdar' and water 'Akhdar'. That is why the agricultural land of Iraq was called Al-Sawad (The Black) due to the abundance and greenness of trees.

**Al-Hutay'ah** (The Runt): His name is Jarwal bin Malik. Named so for his shortness.

**Al-Uqayshir** (The Little Pealed/Red): His name is Uqba. Named for the intense redness of his skin. He said:
'I am Al-Aqshar, that is my title (nazb)... I am the one whose people know my lineage.'
Nazb is an anagram of Nabz (nickname).

**Al-Uqayshir** (Another one): Al-Mughira bin Abdullah. He used to get angry if called Al-Uqayshir. Someone called him that, so he replied:
'You call me Al-Uqayshir, that is my name... And I call you Son of the Lamp-Extinguisher.'
So that man was named 'Son of the Lamp-Extinguisher'.

**Al-Akhtal**: Ghiyath bin Ghawth. Named for the size of his ears (flabby ears). Also means foolish or quick/erroneous in speech. One of his nicknames was **Dawbal**. Jarir said:
'Dawbal wept, may Allah not dry his tears... Indeed, only a Dawbal weeps from humiliation.'

When Al-Akhtal heard this verse, he said: 'May Allah disgrace him. By Allah, my mother named me this for only one day when I was a child; where did this malicious one get it from?'

**Al-Farazdaq**: His name is Hammam bin Ghalib. Named Al-Farazdaq because he had a round, grim face. It was said: 'As if his face is a Farazdaqa,' which is a large round loaf of bread. It is also said: Farazdaq is the crumbled bread (fatut) a woman eats. Someone from Medina criticized him, saying: 'By Allah, we know Al-Farazdaq only as this crumbs a woman eats and throws up.' He replied: 'Praise be to Allah who placed me in the bellies of your women.'

**Al-Zibriqan**: His name is Husayn bin Badr. Named Al-Zibriqan because he had a light beard. Or because he was handsome, likened to the moon (Al-Zibriqan). Or because he wore a dyed (muzabraq) suit.

**Al-Tirimmah**: His name is Hakam bin Hakim. Named for his tallness or his pride (lifting his head).

**Abu Qatifah**: Amr bin al-Walid. Named because he was very hairy (like plush cloth).

**Al-Arqat**: Humayd bin Malik. Named for marks (spots) on his face.

**Al-Afwah**: Named for having thick lips and protruding teeth.

**Al-Najashi**: Named for his intense blackness.

**Jahdar**: Rabi'a bin Dabi'a. Named for his shortness.

**Ziyad al-A'jam**: Named Al-A'jam because he was born and raised in Persia.

**Sadif**: Ismail bin Maymun. Named for his color resembling darkness (Sadaf).

**Abu Nuwas**: Al-Hasan bin Hani. Named for a lock of hair (Nuwas) on his head, or locks hanging on his shoulders. A story says a neighbor called him 'Nuwas' (hanging/moving lock) when he was a boy playing.

**Hammad Ajrad**: Hammad bin Amr. Named Ajrad because he was muscular and hairless (naked of hair).

**Abu al-Atahiya**: Named so as a nickname. 'Atahiya' means foolishness or distraction, or cunning.

**Al-Uth** (The Moth): Zayd bin Ma'ruf. Named because he was a glutton (like a moth eating wool).

**Urwa al-Sa'alik** (Urwa of the Vagabonds): Urwa bin al-Ward. Named because he gathered the poor (Sa'alik) and cared for them.

**Al-Muqanna'** (The Veiled): Muhammad bin Umayr. Named because he was the most beautiful of his time; if he unveiled his face, he feared the evil eye/spirits, so he remained veiled.

**Alqama al-Fahl** (The Stallion): Alqama bin Abda. Named 'The Stallion' because he and Imru' al-Qays disputed over poetry. They appointed Imru' al-Qays's wife, Umm Jundab, as judge. She told them to describe a horse. Imru' al-Qays used verses implying he beat the horse to make it run. Alqama described the horse running swiftly without needing beating. She ruled in favor of Alqama. Imru' al-Qays said: 'You are not a better poet, but you love him.' He divorced her, and Alqama married her (hence 'The Stallion'). Al-Jahiz offered a different explanation involving castration.

**Al-Burk**: Awf bin Malik. Named Al-Burk because he hamstrung his beast (baraka) in a mountain pass during war.

**Al-Find**: Shahl bin Shayban. Named Al-Find (Great Stone/Mountain) because he led a small group effectively in his old age.

**Zayd al-Khayl** (Zayd of the Horses): Zayd bin Muhalhil. Named for his many horses and raids. The Prophet (PBUH) renamed him Zayd al-Khayr (Zayd of Goodness).

**Antara al-Fawaris** (Antara of the Knights): Antara bin Shaddad. Named for engaging many knights.

**Sulayk al-Maqanib**: Sulayk bin Amr. Named for his raids.

**Al-Fatik** (The Assassin): Abdullah bin al-Hasan. Named for his boldness in war.

**Al-Mudhallaq** (The Sharp-Pointed): Aws bin Abbad. His spear always pierced.

**Al-Musayyab**: Zuhayr bin Rabi'a. Named for a verse saying 'Tell Musayyab to pasture' (implying neglect/leaving).

**Faqid Thaqif** (The Missing One of Thaqif): Amr bin Abdullah. He loved his brother's wife. A doctor (Al-Harith bin Kalda) got him drunk to diagnose him. He recited poetry revealing his love. When he sobered up and realized he had exposed himself, he fled in shame and was never seen again.

**Yazid al-Ghawani**: Yazid bin Suwayd. Named because he talked to beauties (Ghawani). He asked to be called Yazid al-Fawaris (of the Knights) instead.

**The Two Majnuns** (Madmen): Majnun of Banu Amir (Qays bin Mu'adh - Layla's lover) and Majnun of Banu Ja'da (Mahdi bin al-Mulawwah). Named for excessive madness/love. Al-Asma'i argued Qays wasn't insane but had 'lawtha' (eccentricity).

**Qays al-Ruqayyat**: Ubaydullah bin Qays. Named because he courted three women named Ruqayyah.

**Ta'abbata Sharran** (He carried evil under his arm): Because he carried a snake or a ghoul under his arm.

**Al-Husam** (The Sword): Hassan bin Thabit. His tongue was as sharp as a sword.

**Al-La'in al-Minqari** (The Cursed): Expelled/cursed by his tribe for a crime.

**Miskin al-Darimi** (The Poor): Named 'Miskin' because he asked his family for help in poverty.

**Al-Qarizan**: Two men from Anazah and Yashkur who went to gather acacia leaves and never returned (proverbial).

**Al-Ra'i** (The Shepherd): Ubayd bin al-Husayn. Named for his descriptions of camels.

**Al-Jaful**: Named because camels were frightened (jafalat) by him.

**Al-Qattal** (The Killer): Abdullah bin al-Mudrahhi. Named for killing many.

**Yasar al-Kawa'ib**: A black slave who thought women loved him. He misunderstood his master's wife's laughter, entered her room, and she castrated him. He fled and became a proverb.

**Chapter: Poets Nicknamed for an Action or Habit**

**Adl al-Asirrah**: Imru' al-Qays bin al-Hammam. Named because his mother put him in a saddlebag (Adl) used for camel-teat ties (Asirrah) when he was born during travel.

**Al-Mudarrab**: Uqba bin Ka'b bin Zuhayr. Named because he was beaten (durriba) by the brothers of a woman he loved.

**Thabit Qutna**: Thabit bin Ka'b. Named because he put cotton (qutna) on an injured eye.

**Dhu al-Isba' al-Adwani**: Named for a snake bite on his finger or having an extra finger.

**Chapter: Those Whose Mother's Name Prevailed Over the Father's**

**Ibn al-Haddadiyya**: Qays bin Munqidh.
**Khufaf bin Nudba**: Nudba was his mother (black). One of the 'Crows of the Arabs'.
**Amr bin al-Atnaba**.
**Al-Ashhab bin Rumayla**.
**Shabib bin al-Barsa'**.
**Ibn Anqa'**.
**Ibn Sahiyya**.
**Ibn Umm Dhubyan**.
**Ibn Umm Sahib**.
**Ibn Mayyada**.
**Ibn Shalwa**.
**Ibn Dara**.
**Ibn al-Tathriya**.
**Ibn Qash'am**.
**Ibn Dabba**.
**Ibn al-Dumayna**.
**Ibn Ghazala**.
**Ibn al-Tayfan**.

**Chapter: Those Attributed to Their Fathers**

Ibn Qaranbul, Ibn al-Zarib, Ibn al-Kharj, Ibn Jadhl al-Ta'an, Ibn al-Ajlan, Ibn Harma, Ibn al-Raqa', Ibn Muqbil.

**The Deep-Rooted (Mu'arraqun) Poets**

A 'Mu'arraq' poet is one who has a lineage of poets (five or so). Example: **Al-Awwam bin al-Mudarrab** (Uqba bin Ka'b bin Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma). Five generations of poets.

**Lineage of Abu Sulma**

Abu Sulma's name: Rabi'a bin Riyah. His sons Zuhayr and Aws were poets, as was his daughter Khansa. From Zuhayr came Bujair and Ka'b. From Ka'b came Uqba. From Uqba came Shabib, Al-Awwam, and Sayf. Al-Awwam is the poet among Uqba's sons.

Poetry of Abu Sulma regarding rain and valleys.
Poetry of Aws (son of Zuhayr).
Poetry of Khansa bint Zuhayr regarding fate.

**Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma**: One of the four stallions of Jahiliyyah poetry. Umar bin al-Khattab praised him highly to Ibn Abbas, calling him the 'Poet of Poets' because he did not use obscure language (mu'azalah) and praised men only for what they possessed. Umar cited his verse on the envy of noble people.

Famous wisdom verses of Zuhayr:
'Whoever goes abroad considers the enemy a friend...'
'Whoever does not protect his cistern with his weapons...'
'Whoever fears the causes of death, they will catch him...'

**Bujair and Ka'b sons of Zuhayr**: Discussion on who was the better poet. Bujair accepted Islam first and witnessed the conquest of Mecca and Hunayn. Ka'b mocked him in verse ('Who will convey to Bujair...').

The Prophet (PBUH) outlawed Ka'b's blood. Bujair warned Ka'b. Ka'b came to the Prophet (PBUH) seeking protection and recited his famous poem 'Banat Su'ad' (Su'ad Has Departed). The Prophet accepted his repentance and threw his Burda (cloak) over him. This Burda was later bought by Muawiyah and worn by Caliphs.

Interaction between Ka'b and Al-Hutay'ah: Al-Hutay'ah asked Ka'b to mention him in poetry as a successor. Ka'b obliged.

Poetry of **Al-Awwam bin Uqba bin Ka'b bin Zuhayr**: A love poem about a 'black' woman (likely meaning beautiful dark features).

**Fatima and Yazid**, children of Sa'id bin Abd al-Rahman bin Hassan bin Thabit. A family of poets.

**Hassan bin Thabit**: The Prophet's Poet. Lived 120 years (60 in Jahiliyyah, 60 in Islam). Used his poetry to defend the Prophet (PBUH) aided by the Holy Spirit (Gabriel). He was more effective against the Quraish than arrows because he knew their genealogies and could satirize them effectively without insulting the Prophet's lineage. Anecdote about Al-Hutay'ah praising the Ansar on his deathbed citing Hassan's verse.

Hassan's pride in his poetry. Anecdote of his daughter completing a verse for him when he got stuck.

**Abd al-Rahman bin Hassan**: Born of Sirin (sister of Mariya al-Qibtiyya). He was stung by a wasp as a child and described it poetically to his father. He lived a long life like his ancestors but died before 60. His poetry samples.

**Sa'id bin Abd al-Rahman**: Poetry samples.
**Fatima bint Sa'id**: Poetry samples on asking for good from noble people.

**Muhammad bin Amara bin Uqayl bin Bilal bin Jarir**: A poetic lineage. Introduction to **Jarir**.

**Al-Khatfi** (Jarir's grandfather): Named for 'snatching' pace.
**Jarir**: His children and wives. The great trio of Islamic poetry: Jarir, Al-Farazdaq, Al-Akhtal. Al-Akhtal's assessment: Jarir scoops from a sea, Farazdaq carves from rock. Jarir defeated many poets. Anecdote about his mother's dream of giving birth to a rope/snake. Jarir's mastery of all genres: Satire, Praise, Nasib (Love). His elegy for his wife.

Jarir's religious poetry. Story of **Umm Ghaylan** (Jarir's daughter) and the rejected suitor, leading to satire.
**Bilal bin Jarir**: Elegy for his father.
**Uqayl bin Bilal**: His encounter with a Bedouin woman regarding a verse.
**Amara bin Uqayl**: The most poetic of Jarir's descendants. His poetry on Khalid (praise) and wisdom verses.

Amara bin Uqayl's poetry on aging and blindness. Comparison with Abu Tammam (he preferred Abu Tammam). His satire of Baghdad. The author praises Baghdad and the current Caliph.

**Marwan bin Abi Hafsa Family**: A deep-rooted poetic family.
**Marwan al-Akbar** (The Elder): Praise of Al-Mahdi. His famous poem 'A visitor knocked...'. Support for Abbasid legitimacy over Alids.

Marwan's political poetry. His opinion on Jarir, Farazdaq, and Akhtal. Story of his access to Caliph Al-Mahdi being blocked by the minister Yaqub bin Dawud, and how he bypassed him using a poem recited by the Chamberlain, leading to his success.

Marwan's large reward from Al-Mahdi and his family. His elegy for Al-Mahdi. His praise for Al-Hadi and Harun al-Rashid. He died in 181 AH.

**Marwan al-Asghar** (The Younger): Prominent in the time of Al-Mutawakkil. Anti-Alid poetry. Huge reward from Al-Mutawakkil. Envy of other poets (Shafi'i, Jammaz, Buhturi) and their satire against him.

Conflict with Ali bin al-Jahm. **Mahmud bin Marwan**. **Mutawwaj bin Mahmud**: Praise of Al-Muwaffaq describing the naval battle against the Zanj rebellion. **Idris bin Abi Hafsa**: Elegy for Ishaq al-Mawsili. **Muhammad bin Idris**: His strange poetry style.

**Amina bint al-Walid**: Poetess of the family.
**Abu al-Samt** (Marwan): Improvising praise for Abdullah bin Tahir.
**Razin Family**: Ali bin Razin, Di'bil, Abu al-Shis.
**Di'bil al-Khuza'i**: Prolific and sharp-tongued. Anecdote of a poetic gathering with Abu Nuwas, Muslim bin al-Walid, and Abu al-Shis.

Conclusion of the gathering (Abu Nuwas wins). Di'bil's satire of Al-Ma'mun (regarding the killing of his brother Amin). Ibrahim al-Mahdi urges punishment, but Ma'mun tolerates it after reading the satire. Di'bil's satire on the death of a Caliph.
Di'bil's satire on the crucifixion of Ahmad bin Nasr. Di'bil on the survival of his poetry. His wisdom poetry (patience, self-respect).

Di'bil's poetry on brevity and fame. Di'bil and his brother in Egypt with Al-Muttalib, and the story of the hidden poet Ahmad bin al-Sarraj. **Abu al-Shis**: His 'clipped wing' poem presented to Bashar bin Burd.

Abu al-Shis's poetry (Hardships, Praise of Al-Amin/Elegy for Al-Rashid). Description of a cupbearer and a lover. **Abdullah bin Abi al-Shis**: Elegy for Abu Tammam. Satire of Samarra (Surra Man Ra'a) and its climate.

Abdullah's satire continued. Hasan bin Wahb's support for him. Abdullah's apology poem.
**Abu Suwayd Abd al-Qawi** (Descendant of Abu al-Atahiya).
**Abu al-Atahiya**: The great ascetic poet. Praise of his natural style. His repentance from love poetry due to a dream.

Abu al-Atahiya at a gathering with Abu Amr al-Shaybani, Muslim bin al-Walid, and Abu Nuwas. Abu al-Atahiya's verses on death and the fleeting nature of life. Comparison of his verses with others regarding the increase of age being a decrease in life.

Abu al-Atahiya on grey hair as a harbinger of death. Interaction with Abu Nuwas writing verses on God's creation. Themes of fearing death only when mentioned, otherwise negligent. Comparisons with Ibn Durayd and others.

Bashar accusing Abu al-Atahiya of stealing a poetic image. Abu al-Atahiya's innovative meanings in love/sympathy. His relationship with Caliph Al-Hadi (fear and praise) and Al-Rashid. Improvising a poem about the milestone shadow during Hajj.

Abu al-Atahiya's late poetry. His son and grandson's poetry.
**Rajaz Poets**: Lineage of Al-Ajjaj and Ru'ba. **Al-Ajjaj**: The first to lengthen the Rajaz meter. Comparison to Imru' al-Qays. His family conflicts (Satirizing his son).
More Al-Ajjaj vs Ru'ba. Anecdotes with Caliphs. **Ru'ba bin al-Ajjaj**: Conflict with his father over favoritism. Ru'ba proving his poetic skill. Father admits Ru'ba's talent ('Divorce your mother').
Ru'ba and Al-Ajjaj disputing poetry before Abd al-Malik. Linguistic note on 'Ru'ba'. Ru'ba with Abu Muslim al-Khurasani. Ru'ba on bribery.

Ru'ba with Kumayt and Tirimmah. **The Brothers (Shammakh, Muzarrad, Jaz')**: Story of scaring off their mother's suitor. Shammakh's poetry (Donkeys, decision making). Praise of Araba al-Awsi. Anecdote with Al-Rashid rewarding Al-Asma'i for Shammakh's verse.
Muzarrad's poetry. **Dhu al-Rumma**: Critiques by Jarir and Farazdaq (Good at description, bad at praise/satire). Considered the best Islamic poet in similes.
Dhu al-Rumma and **Mayy** (He loved her without seeing her, trick played on him). Dhu al-Rumma and **Kharqa**. His death. His brothers Mas'ud and Hisham.
**Banu Murra al-Qirdi**: Ten poet brothers. **Abu Khurash al-Hudhali**: Elegy for his brother Urwa. His son Khurash's escape from death. Abu Khurash's poetry on hunger and death.

**Abu Jundab**: Elegy. **Poets among Commanders**: The Tahirid family. **Tahir bin al-Husayn (Dhu al-Yamanayn)**: Conqueror of Baghdad. His poetic correspondence with Ibrahim al-Mahdi and Al-Ma'mun regarding power and fate.
Tahir's poetry on killing Amin and ruling. His eloquence. His response to Ma'mun's suspicion. **Abdullah bin Tahir**: Better poet than his father. His poetry on wealth and glory.
Abdullah bin Tahir's poetry on serving guests and bravery. Love poetry. His famous poem on aging ('Clouds of youth cleared...'). Elegy for his brother.

Abdullah's elegy continued. **Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir**: Prolific poet. Poetry on amputation (metaphor for loss). Love poetry. **Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir**: Correspondence with his brother during illness.
Muhammad bin Abdullah's generosity with Judge Sawar. His descriptive poetry (Rain, hunting scene details).
Muhammad's hunting poem continued. Love poetry. **Sulayman bin Abdullah**: Short verses. **Poets among Scribes (Katib)**: Introduction and praise of the Abbasid Caliph (Al-Mustansir) by the author.
Praise of the Caliph continued. **Yaqub bin al-Rabi'**: Story of his love for the slave girl Mulk. Seven years of pursuit. Poetry on distraction vs. obsession in love.
Debate on curing love. Yaqub attains Mulk, she dies shortly after. His intense grief and poetry. Theme of joy and grief being close (Wedding/Funeral). Comparisons with other elegies.

Themes of dying together. Story of **Tarab** (replacement for Mulk) also dying. Yaqub's despair. **Muhammad bin Abdullah al-Mawsili's** commentary on a specific verse about becoming accustomed to calamities.
More on the theme of calamities. **Ibrahim bin al-Abbas al-Suli**: His high-quality poetry. Themes of generosity, tribal defense, and praise of Fadl bin Sahl and Abdullah bin Tahir.
Ibrahim's elegies. Poetry on friendship and betrayal. Letter to Ishaq bin Ibrahim. Anecdote of the recommendation letter for Abu al-Hudhayl with a double meaning. Description of a singing girl.
More Ibrahim al-Suli. **Sa'id bin Humayd**: His poetry on admonition and brevity of life. Themes of eyes betraying the heart. Love poetry (Sun is near yet far).
Sa'id bin Humayd: Accepting excuses, thanking for injustice. Leaving a place of humiliation. Heart traveling while body stays. Wine poetry. Description of music.
Sa'id's nature poetry (Spring, 'Earth laughing/Sky weeping'). Regret over wasted time. Elegy for Abdullah bin Salih.
Sa'id's satire. **Ahmad bin Yusuf**: Poetry on illness and fickleness of heart. Distance vs. Proximity of hearts.
More Ahmad bin Yusuf. **Al-Hasan and Sulayman (Sons of Wahb)**: Hasan's letters and poetry from prison to Mutawakkil and his brother. Praise of Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad.
Hasan bin Wahb praising Sulayman. Love poetry referencing 'Banan'. **Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik al-Zayyat**: His political poetry inciting Ma'mun against Ibrahim al-Mahdi.
Ibn al-Zayyat's poetry about his horse. Praise of Mu'tasim. Conflict with Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad. His imprisonment, torture, and satire. Poetry from prison.

**Al-Hasan bin Raja**: Praise of Ma'mun. **Slave Poets (Ubayd al-Arab)**: List of names (Nusayb, Maysara, etc.). Poem by **Ruh bin al-Ta'ifiyya** boasting of them. **Nusayb**: Black slave poet, noble and generous. Anecdote about buying his cousin Suhaym.
Nusayb's interactions with Sukayna bint al-Husayn, Maslama bin Abd al-Malik, and Abdullah bin Ja'far. Kuthayyir and Jamil trying to intimidate him. Nusayb with Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik and Farazdaq.

Nusayb vs Jarir. **Abd Bani al-Has-has (Suhaym)**: Boasting of his character. His famous poem describing a secret rendezvous. **Wizr**. **Maysara (Abu al-Darda)**. **Maysara (Abu Nasr)**: Conflict with Banu Darim and Farazdaq.
Maysara challenging Farazdaq. **Warak** and the camel. **Dhakwan** (Fast traveler). **Muwarraq** (Fear of his master).

Muwarraq's satire. **Dhu al-Rukba**. **Al-Mundalith**. **Al-Hayqatan** (Satire with Jarir). **Zamil**. **Abu al-Tayyar**. **Al-Muthallim**. **Al-Hazar**. **Abu Ata al-Sindi** (Heavy accent, hired a reciter).
Abu Ata continued. **Duhayqin**. **Madam**. **Bistam**. **Lahdham**. **Al-Mirqal**. **Shunayr**. **Jandal**. **Abu Dulama**: Famous jester/poet. Trickery to get rewards from Al-Mansur.
Abu Dulama obtaining land. Anecdote with Al-Mahdi and the dog. Story of being drunk and imprisoned in the chicken coop by Al-Mansur. His poem from the coop.
Abu Dulama pardoned. **Slave Women Poets**: **Inan**: Witty slave of Natifi. Interactions with Harun al-Rashid, Yahya bin Khalid, and Abu Nuwas.
Inan with the Bedouin and Isa bin Ja'far. Satire of Abu Nuwas. Praise of Ja'far al-Barmaki. **Al-Dhalfa'**: Interaction with Marwan bin Abi Hafsa and Abu Nuwas.
Al-Dhalfa' with Abbas bin al-Ahnaf. **Rim**. **Fadl**: Exchanges with Sa'id bin Humayd. **Khansa**. **Mulk**. **Saraf**. **Khushf**. **Alam**.
**Mudam**. **Rayya**. **Mukhannatha**: Satire of Abu Nuwas. **Sakan**: Praise of Abu Dulaf.
Story of a slave girl who loved her master. **Madmen Poetry**: **Abu Hayya al-Numayri** (Eccentric, not mad). His poetry.
Abu Hayya's love poetry. **Mani al-Majnun**: Descriptions of eyes/sleep. Anecdote with Abu Dulaf regarding a horse.
Mani's love poetry. **Juaifran al-Majnun**: Satire of someone who criticized his poetry.
Juaifran's escape and satire. **Abbas al-Mashuq**: Satire of Basra. **Khalid al-Katib** (Al-Muswas). Conclusion.
